title: Investigation of Transformer Model for TRV Calculation by EMTP
abstract: Analysis of the EMTP transformer model was performed with the 4kVA two windings low voltage transformer with the current injection (CIJ) measurement method to study a transient recovery voltage (TRV) at the transformer limited fault (TLF) current interrupting condition. Tested transformer's impedance was measured by the frequency response analyzer (FRA). From FRA measurement graphs leakage inductance, stray capacitance and resistance were calculated. The EMTP transformer model was constructed with those values. The EMTP simulation was done for a current injection circuit by using transformer model. The experiment and simulation results show a reasonable agreement.

Extended Summary ຊจ͸ pp.1174–1180
Investigation of Transformer Model for TRV Calculation by EMTP
Myo Min Thein Student Member (Kyushu Institute of Technology, g346455m@tobata.isc.kyutech.ac.jp)
Hisatoshi Ikeda Senior Member (Kyushu Institute of Technology, ikeda@ele.kyutech.ac.jp)
Katsuhiko Harada Member (Kyushu Institute of Technology, harada@ele.kyutech.ac.jp)
Shinya Ohtsuka Member (Kyushu Institute of Technology, ohtsuka@ele.kyutech.ac.jp)
Masayuki Hikita Senior Member (Kyushu Institute of Technology, hikita@ele.kyutech.ac.jp)
Eiichi Haginomori Life Member (Chuo University, haginomori@mx6.ttcn.ne.jp)
Tadashi Koshiduka Member (Toshiba Corporation, tadashi.koshiduka@toshiba.co.jp)
Keywords: transient recovery voltage, transform er limited fault, frequency response analysi s, accurate impedance value, trans-
former equivalent circuit, EMTP
Since very large capacity power transformers are used in the elec-
tric power system, the transformer limited fault current (TLFC) be-
came to exceed interrupting current of the T10 test condition be-
cause a small leakage impedance of large capacity power transform-
ers. The transformer model for a t ransient recovery voltage (TRV)
at the TLFC interrupting conditions was studied with the current in-
jection (CIJ) measurement and the TRV calculation was investigated
with alternative transients program-electromagnetic transients pro-
gram (ATP-EMTP).
For the ﬁrst step study, the 4 kV A two windings low voltage trans-
former was used because of its simpleness of winding conﬁguration.
Figure 1 shows experiment circui t diagram. To study an inherent
TRV of the TLF condition which is dominated by a transformer
impedance the CIJ measurement method was used.
The EMTP model circuit was expressed in Fig. 2. To construct
Fig. 1. Experiment circuit diagram
Fig. 2. EMTP model circuit
EMTP model the test transformer impedance is needed. The fre-
quency response analysis (FRA) was used to measure the impedance
of the test transformer. The transformer equivalent elements, such
as leakage inductance, stray capac itance and resistances were de-
rived from frequency versus impedance graph. We presented exper-
iment procedures, results, consider ations for transformer constants
and constructed EMTP transformer models of current interrupting
condition for TRV calculation of tested transformer in this paper.
The constructed EMTP model circuit gives agreeable results with
the experiment. The main voltage oscillation and the TRV oscilla-
tion waves of experiment are expressed in Fig. 3. Figure 4 is the
EMTP simulation results.
From this experiment it was known that the TRV at the TLF cur-
rent interrupting condition can be studied by the CIJ measurement
method. The ideal EMTP model circuit can be constructed. The
transformer constants to be used in EMTP model circuit can be
calculated from FRA measurement graphs. The relation between
circuit parameters (capacitances , inductances and resistances) and
voltage oscillation waves were understood.
Fig. 3. Experiment results
Fig. 4. EMTP simulation results

Analysis of the EMTP transformer model was performed with the 4 kV A two windings low voltage transformer with
the current injection (CIJ) measurement method to study a transient recovery voltage (TRV) at the transformer limited
fault (TLF) current interrupting condition. Tested transformer’s impedance was measured by the frequency response
analyzer (FRA). From FRA measurement graphs leakage induc tance, stray capacitance and resistance were calcu-
lated. The EMTP transformer model was constructed with those values. The EMTP simulation was done for a current
injection circuit by using transformer model. The experiment and simulation results show a reasonable agreement.
Keywords: transient recovery voltage, transform er limited fault, frequency response analysi s, accurate impedance value, trans-
former equivalent circuit, EMTP
1. Introduction
Due to an increase of electric power consumption the ca-
pacity of an electric power system is growing. To fulﬁll
the power demand, large capacity power transformers have
been used in high voltage power transmission systems es-
pecially above 200 kV . As the transformers have small leak-
age impedance, when a fault occurs in the power system, the
transformer limited fault (TLF) current became to exceed an
interrupting current of the T10 test condition relevant to the
IEC standard. After current interrupting occurs by a circuit
breaker (CB) due to the power system fault, CB is needed to
endure a transient recovery voltage (TRV) to keep an elec-
tricity distribution and operations of the power system. Since
a fault current of the TLF condition becomes to exceed the
T10 condition, a separate test has been adopted with a current
level higher than that at T10. The TRV should be investigated
carefually at the TLF condition so that a circuit breaker is not
tested under unnecessarily severe conditions.
Although there were several researches to investigate
TRVs at the TLF condition
(1) (2), the most case used the values
of a leakage inductance of 50 /60 Hz and a stray capacitance
to analyze TRVs by using Electromagnetic Transient Pro-
gram (EMTP). A phenomenon has been known about mag-
netic ﬂux which will not be able to enter an iron core of a
transformer winding at high frequency regions. Therefore
∗Kyushu Institute of Technology
1-1, Sensuicho, Tobata-ku, Kita-kyushu 804-8550
∗∗Chuo University
13-27, Kasuga-1, Bunkyo-ku, Tokyo 112-8551

2-1, Ukichimacho, Kawasaki-ku, Kawasaki 210-0862
the leakage inductance will change along with the frequency.
A leakage inductance of 50 /60 Hz may give wrong TRV . A
transformer consists of very complex components compos-
ing a network of resistances, capacitances and self or mutual
inductances.
For the purpose of calculating TRVs accurately at TLF
conditions, with equivalent circuit elements at the TRV fre-
quency range around 10 ∼100 kHz, the ﬁrst step research
study with two windings low voltage transformer model was
conducted.
In this report, the consideration and calculation for wind-
ing resistances, leakage inductances and stray capacitances of
a test transformer are presented to obtain an accurate trans-
former model.
2. Transformer Limited Fault
The TLF is one of fault that occurs in an electric power
system. The fault clearing case in an actual power system is
shown in Figs. 1(a) and (b). The TLF interrupting is deﬁned
as a fault where all fault currents are supplied through a trans-
former. Figure 1(b) represents the equivalent circuit diagram
of the TLF interrupting condition in an electric power sys-
tem. In the case of a TRV related to the TLF current interrupt-
ing condition, while short-circuit currents are generally much
smaller than the rated short-circuited current but it is certain
that a severe TRV may result because of low impedances
mainly due to the transformer stray capacitance
(3) (4).T h e
transformer stray capacitance occurs from winding to wind-
ing, from turn to turn, from windings to core and from wind-
ing to ground. The capacitance from winding to ground is
the most dominant parameter on TRV than the other trans-
former capacitances. During the TLF the majority of the
c⃝2009 The Institute of Electrical Engineers of Japan. 1174
Transformer Model for TRV Calculation by EMTP
(a) Equivalent circuit for TLF clearing
(b) TLF interrupting in power system
Fig. 1. TLF interrupting circuit diagram
voltage shares by the transformer impedance X Tr,s ot h a t
TRV after the fault current interrupting is mostly generated
by the relevant transformer constants (5). To construct EMTP
transformer model it was needed to know the test transformer
impedance.
3. Impedance Measurement
3.1 FRA Measurement The frequency response
analysis (FRA) is a powerful diagnostic technique and be-
came popular for an examination of a transformer internal
conditions
(6). It can measure the impedance of transformer
windings over a wide range of frequencies. This property
was used well in our research by converting the FRA mea-
surement raw data to impedances in ohm values versus fre-
quency. The transformer impedance was measured by a fre-
quency response analyzer (NF FRA 5059), the measurable
frequency range of which is between 0.1 mHz to 2.2 MHz.
The schematic diagram of transformer winding impedance
measurement is expressed in Fig. 2.
The FRA measurement was done from both sides of the
test transformer. The FRA measurement from the secondary
winding while the primary winding is short-circuited did not
give the resonance point up to 2.2 MHz. The measurement at
the primary winding while the secondary is short-circuited
gave the complete result shown in Fig. 3(a). Which was
used to calculate the transformer impedance and then re-
sults were converted to the secondary side values by the test
transformer’s turn ratio. The measured impedance near
the resonance frequency region is shown in Fig. 3(b) and
the measured impedance below 10 Hz is shown in Fig. 3(c)
respectively.
3.2 Impedance Calculation Actually it is better if a
frequency dependent inductance model can be used in TRV
investigation. At the moment there is no EMTP inductance
model of frequency dependent. For the ﬁrst step of our study,
the leakage inductance (Lt) was evaluated by averaging the
impedance values between 500 Hz to 100 kHz. The stray ca-
pacitance (Ct) was calculated from a resonance point of the
FRA graph (at 0.27 MHz) with applying the calculated leak-
age inductance value. The ﬁrst EMTP transformer model of
the tested 4 kV A two windings low voltage transformer was
modeled by these values. Fig. 4 is the equivalent transformer
Fig. 2. FRA measurement setup diagram
(a) FRA graph that is used to calculate transformer impedance
(1 Hz ∼2.2 MHz)
(b) FRA graph that is used to calculate damping resistor (100 kHz∼2.2 MHz)
(c) FRA graph that is used to calculate winding resistance at very low
frequency (1 Hz ∼10 Hz)
Fig. 3. FRA measurement graphs of test transformer in
diﬀerent frequency values
model circuit that was used in the ﬁrst step EMTP simula-
tion. In Fig. 4, Lt is the leakage inductance and Ct is the stray
capacitance of the tested transformer. The stray capacitance
Ct is assumed to include all stray capacitance related to the
TRV . R was adopted for a damping resistance in the TRV os-
cillation and it was a ﬁtting parameter. In the ﬁrst step EMTP
transformer model the damping resistance value was justiﬁed
to get the same EMTP simulation TRV result with the exper-
iment result
(5) (7).

impedance value of the transformer, the following calcula-
tion was performed. This calculation is based on calculated

Finding the way to calculate the damping resistance value
is essential in the next step of EMTP model. To obtain the
accurate model of the tested transformer, the ideal equivalent
models are considered as in Figs. 7(a) and (b). Fig. 7(b) is
considered as there will be some parallel resistance with the
stray capacitance due to a skin eﬀect of windings and an iron
loss at a high frequency region. Rt is the winding resistance
at very low frequency region and it was obtained from FRA
measurement of Fig. 3(c).
EMTP simulation was done with both considered models
Figs. 7(a) and (b). Simulation results of Fig. 7(a) gave the
agreeable results with the experiment. The simulation result
of Fig. 7(b) showed a very short decay of vibration compares
with the experiment.
It is necessary to ﬁnd the damping resistor value used
in this model instead of a ﬁtting value. According to the
FRA graph of Fig. 3(a), the transformer winding impedance
is varying with depending on the frequency. At the resonance
point (0.27 MHz) the impedance value will be same as R in
Fig. 7(a) because of jωLt

small. Then, Rp, resistance of test transformer at resonace
point that is determined from FRA graph of Fig. 3(b), was
calculated at 2100 Ω.

By solving the Eq. (2) with Rp =2100 Ω, Ct∗=1.18 nF at
resonance frequency of 0.27 MHz, R became 112.47Ω.T h i s
is primary side value. Converting to secondary side value ac-

This value is agreeable with 5 Ωthat was used in ﬁrst step
EMTP model of Fig. 4.
4. Experiment
4.1 Transformer for Experiment 4 kV A two wind-
ings low voltage transformer was used for our study because
of its simpleness of winding conﬁguration. Transformer
speciﬁcation are expressed in Table 2.
4.2 Current Injection Measurement The TRV can
be investigated by both current interrupting and current injec-
tion (CIJ) methods. The former one includes various factors
aﬀecting on a TRV shape such as current chopping and the
arcing voltage of interrupting equipments (3) (8). To investigate
TRV the latter is preferable. The current interrupting can be
expressed by a phenomenon where the opposite polarity cur-
rent is injected after the current zero point. The opposite cur-
rent is only injected at the current injection method which is
theoretically same as the current interrupting.
To investigate TRV at TLF current interrupting condition
we used CIJ measurement circuit that was expressed in Fig. 8.
As expressed in Fig. 1, the power source G supplies the fault
current through the source side impedance and the trans-
former. The circuit breaker CB interrupts the fault current.
By this phenomena the experiment circuit was constructed.
The power source G was short-circuited, L3 (1.87 mH)
a n dR 3( 0 . 7Ω) represented as source side impedance in the
Table 2. Test transformer speciﬁcation
Fig. 8. Schematic CIJ diagram of experiment
(a) Main oscillation
(b)-1 TRV oscillation
(b)-2 TRV oscillation
Fig. 9. Wave shapes of experiment
࿦ Bɼ129ר10ɼ2009 ೥ 1177
Fig. 1(b). The fault was replaced by a current supply cir-
cuit. The current supply circuit was energized by DC sup-
ply. Firstly, the capacitor C (42.7μF) was charged by the DC
voltage supply by swiching the SW1. After charging the ca-
pacitor C, current injection was done with the SW2 (mercury
switch). The values L1 (7.95 mH), L2 (30 μH), R (40 Ω)a n d
R1 (1.3 Ω) are current injection circuit elements. The volt-
ages at transformer primary and secondary sides were mea-
sured by an oscilloscope. The wave shapes of two voltages
are same while the magnitude are di ﬀerent due to the turn
ratio of the transformer. Experiment results of the time dura-
tions 40 ms (main voltage oscillation) and 100 /400 μs( T R V
oscillation wave) are shown in Figs. 9(a), (b)-1 and (b)-2. The
TRV oscillation appears at the starting 400 μso ft h em a i n
voltage oscillation.
5. EMTP Model
The EMTP simulation model circuit for the TRV investi-
gation at TLF current interrupting condition was constructed
and expressed in Fig. 10 (9). Rt is the winding resistance of
the test transformer in a very low frequency region Fig. 3(c).
The circuit constants are mentioned in Table 3. The sim-
ulation results of EMTP model circuit gave the agreeable
results with the experiment. The EMTP results are men-
tioned in Figs. 11(a) and (b)-1 and (b)-2. Fig. 11(a) is the
main voltage oscillation which corresponds to the frequency
that gives the closed circuit by the capacitor C, the induc-
tances L1 +L2, short-circuit impedance L3 and the trans-
former leakage impedance Lt*. Fig. 11(b) is the TRV oscil-
lation which corresponds to the TRV determined by Lt*, L3
and the transformer stray capacitance Ct* of EMTP simula-
tion with damping resistance R.
To get the agreeable EMTP result in TRV wave shape with
the experiment, the damping resistor R is essential in EMTP
model circuit Fig. 10. The EMTP simulation result for TRV
without damping resistance value is expressed in Fig. 11(c).
Fig. 10. Accurate EMTP model
Table 3. Circuit constants of Fig. 10
(a) Main oscillation
(b)-1 TRV oscillation
(b)-2 TRV oscillation
(c) TRV oscillation without damping resistance
Fig. 11. V oltage graphs of accurate EMTP model
6. Discussion
Let us discuss the results of the experiment and EMTP sim-
ulation results:-
From the main voltage oscillation, Figs. 9(a) and 11(a), it is
1178 IEEJ Trans. PE, Vol.129, No.10, 2009
Transformer Model for TRV Calculation by EMTP
obvious that good agreeable results with the experiment and
the simulation. From the EMTP simulation it was understood
that the inductance and the capacitance of current supply cir-
cuit mainly inﬂuenced on the main voltage oscillation wave.
From the TRV oscillation wave, Figs. 9(b) and 11(b),
agreeable results are seen between the experiment and the
simulation. From EMTP simulation it was understood that
the leakage inductance and the stray capacitance of the test
transformer mainly inﬂuenced on this TRV oscillation wave.
Furthermore, the damping resistor is indispensable in the
EMTP model. Its resistance value determines the TRV os-
cillation to be damped.
7. Conclusions
We obtained the following conclusions for the accurate
TRV calculation by EMTP at the TLF condition.
For the transformer model:-
( 1 ) A leakage impedance can be obtained from FRA by
averaging between the frequency range of 500 Hz to 100 kHz.
( 2 ) A stray capacitance can be obtained from the reso-
nance frequency and calculated leakage impedance.
( 3 ) A damping resistor can be obtained from an
impedance at the resonance frequency.
For current injection method:-
( 1 ) By using the transformer model the EMTP calcula-
tion and the experiment give an agreeable results.
( 2 ) Current injection is not su ﬀered from current chop-
ping and arcing voltage which are main diﬃculities in an in-
terrupting method.
For the future it is desirable to identify the more precise
impedance calculation from FRA measurement graph to use
TRV investigation EMTP model for TLF condition.
(Manuscript received Jan. 10, 2009,
revised April 13, 2009)

Myo Min Thein (Student Member) was born in Meikhtila, Myan-
mar, June 6, 1974. He received the B.E. degree in
Electrical Power Engineering from Yangon Institute
of Technology, Myanmar in 2001. From 2001 to
2003 he worked at Planning Department, from 2003
to 2006 he worked at Power Station as an substation
operation engineer, Myanma Electric Power Enter-
prise, Myanmar. Since 2007, he is a master student
in Kyushu Institute of Technology, Japan.
Hisatoshi Ikeda (Senior Member) entered Toshiba in 1974, after
graduated Tokyo University. In Toshiba he worked
as a research engineer of substation equipment. He
received his doctor degree form Tokyo University in
1990. From 2007, he is a visiting professor of the
funded research laboratory by Kyushu Electric Power
Co. at the Kyushu Institute of Technology. He is Fel-
low of IEEE, a chairman of IEC/SB1 and JICCG and
Senior member of IEEJ.
Katsuhiko Harada (Member) received the B.S. degree in 1994 and
the M.S. degree in 1996 from Kinki University. Since
1996, he has been associated with the Department
of Electrical and Communication Engineering, Kinki
University, where he was a Researcher from 1996 to
1998, a Part-time Lecturer from 1999 to 2007. Since
2007 he has been working as an Assistant Professor
at the Kyushu Institute of Technology. He received
an IEEJ Excellent Presentation Award in 2005. He is
engaged in research on power electronics and photo-
voltaic power generation system.
Shinya Ohtsuka (Member) was born on 16 January 1971. He re-
ceived the B.S., M.S. and Dr. degrees in Electrical
Engineering from Kyushu University, Japan, in 1994,
1996 and 1998, respectively. He was a Research Fel-
low of the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science
(JSPS) from 1996 to 1998 and an Assistant Professor
of the Faculty of Engineering at Kyushu Institute of
Technology, Japan from 1999. Since 2006, he has
been an Associate Professor in Kyushu Institute of
Technology. He has been engaged in researches on
the insulation properties of SF
6 gas and environmentally benign gas, partial
discharge detection technique for insulation diagnosis of power apparatus
and high electric ﬁeld phenomena. Dr. Ohtsuka is a member of the Insti-
tute of Electrical Engineers of Japan (IEEJ), the Institute of Engineers on
Electrical Discharges in Japan (IEEDJ), the Cryogenic Association of Japan,
CIGRE D1.33 and IEEE.
Masayuki Hikita (Senior Member) was born in 1953. He received
B.Sc. and Dr. degrees in electrical engineering from
Nagoya University of Japan, in 1977, 1979, and 1982,
respectively. He was an Assistant, a Lecturer, and As-
sociate Professor at Nagoya University in 1982, 1989,
and 1992, respectively. Since 1996, he has been a
professor of the Department of Electrical Engineer-
ing, Kyushu Institute of Technology. He was Visit-
ing Scientist at the High V oltage Laboratory in MIT,
USA, from August 1985 to July 1987. Dr. Hikita
has recently been interested in research on development of diagnostic tech-
nique of power equipment. He is a member of the Japan Society of Applied
Physics, IEE Japan and Senior member of IEEE.
